scenarios.title: Unaccompanied Minor at RAP
scenarios.description: A 17-year-old arrives alone at the RAP seeking shelter. They state they've been staying with different friends for the past two weeks after their parents kicked them out.
scenarios.question: What is the appropriate action?

options.B: Contact Child Protective Services as they are an unaccompanied minor
options.C: Proceed with regular adult assessment process

scenarios.explanation: Unaccompanied minors under 18 are not eligible for CE and must be referred to appropriate youth services or Child Protective Services. See manual pages 44 for detailed information.

scenarios.title: Family Doubled Up
scenarios.description: A family of four (2 adults, 2 children ages 8 and 12) reports they've been staying with relatives for the past 3 months. The relatives have given them 7 days to leave due to lease violations.
scenarios.question: Are they eligible for CE assessment?

options.A: Yes, they meet the HUD definition of homelessness
options.B: No, they are housed and not literally homeless
options.C: Only if they have documentation from the relatives
options.D: Yes, but only after they actually leave the relative's home

scenarios.explanation: Families doubled up with relatives are not considered literally homeless under HUD's definition. They would need to be in a place not meant for human habitation, emergency shelter, or transitional housing to be eligible. See manual pages 31, 32, 42 for detailed information.

scenarios.title: Living in Vehicle
scenarios.description: A person reports they've been sleeping in their car at a highway rest stop for the past week. The car is registered and operational.
scenarios.question: Does this person meet the definition of literal homelessness?

options.A: No, because they have a vehicle
options.B: Yes, a car is not meant for human habitation
options.C: Only if the car is not operational
options.D: Only if they've been there more than 14 days

scenarios.explanation: A car, even if operational, is considered a place not meant for human habitation. This person meets the HUD definition of literal homelessness. See manual pages 31, 32, 42 for detailed information.
relatedConcepts: Place Not Meant for Human Habitation

scenarios.title: Recent Jail Release
scenarios.description: An individual was released from county jail this morning after serving 120 days. They have no place to go and are seeking shelter.
scenarios.question: Are they eligible for CE assessment?

options.A: No, they were housed in an institution
options.B: Yes, if they were homeless before incarceration
options.C: Yes, they are literally homeless now
options.D: Only after 7 days on the street

scenarios.explanation: The person is currently literally homeless as they have no place to go. Previous institutional stays don't disqualify someone if they are currently experiencing literal homelessness. See manual pages 31, 32, 42 for detailed information.

scenarios.title: Pregnant Young Adult
scenarios.description: A 19-year-old who is 6 months pregnant arrives at the RAP alone. She's been sleeping outside for 3 nights after leaving an abusive relationship.
scenarios.question: What special considerations apply?

options.A: She must be assessed as a family
options.B: She requires immediate shelter placement without assessment
options.C: She should be assessed as a single adult with vulnerability noted
options.D: She is not eligible until the baby is born

scenarios.explanation: A pregnant individual without children present is assessed as a single adult, but pregnancy should be noted as a vulnerability factor that may affect prioritization. See manual pages 5, 36, 44 for detailed information.

scenarios.title: Fleeing Domestic Violence
scenarios.description: A person reports they left their apartment 5 days ago due to domestic violence and have been staying with a friend. The friend can only let them stay 2 more nights.
scenarios.question: What is their current eligibility status?

options.A: Eligible immediately as a DV survivor
options.B: Not eligible - they are currently housed
options.D: Must wait until they leave the friend's place

scenarios.explanation: While fleeing DV, they are currently staying with a friend and are not literally homeless. They would become eligible once they have no safe housing option. See manual pages 15, 16, 31, 32, 42 for detailed information.

scenarios.title: Impending Homelessness
scenarios.description: A young adult has a written eviction notice giving them 10 days to vacate their apartment. They have no resources or place to go.
scenarios.question: Can they receive CE assessment now?

options.A: Yes, they will be homeless in 14 days or less
options.B: No, they must wait until they're actually homeless
options.C: Yes, but only for prevention services
options.D: Only if they have proof of eviction

scenarios.explanation: Young adults (18-24) who are at risk of homelessness within 14 days ARE eligible for CE assessment. This is a special provision for this age group to help prevent them from becoming literally homeless. See manual pages 4, 32, 42 for detailed information.

scenarios.title: Veteran in Transitional Housing
scenarios.description: A veteran has been in VA transitional housing for 18 months. The program is ending and they need permanent housing.
scenarios.question: Are they eligible for CE assessment?

options.A: No, they are housed in a program
options.B: Yes, transitional housing residents are considered homeless
options.C: Only if the program is ending within 14 days

scenarios.explanation: Residents of transitional housing programs are considered literally homeless under HUD's definition and are eligible for CE assessment. See manual pages 31, 32, 42 for detailed information.

scenarios.title: Hospital Discharge
scenarios.description: Hospital social worker calls about a patient being discharged in 2 hours with no place to go. The patient has been hospitalized for 5 days.
scenarios.question: What is the appropriate CE response?

options.A: Complete assessment over the phone with social worker
options.B: Patient must come to RAP after discharge
options.C: Hospital should keep them until housing is found
options.D: Provide shelter bed to prevent discharge to street

scenarios.explanation: The patient needs to be literally homeless to be assessed. They should be referred to come to the RAP after discharge, or staff can do outreach if appropriate. See manual pages 31, 32, 42 for detailed information.

scenarios.title: Family Camping
scenarios.description: A family reports they've been camping in a state park for 2 weeks. They have a tent and camping equipment but no permanent address.
scenarios.question: Do they meet the definition of literal homelessness?

options.B: Yes, camping areas are not meant for habitation
options.C: Only if they're in an unauthorized area

scenarios.explanation: Camping in parks, even with equipment, constitutes living in a place not meant for human habitation and meets the definition of literal homelessness. See manual pages 31, 32, 42 for detailed information.
relatedConcepts: Place Not Meant for Human Habitation

scenarios.title: Motel Voucher Ending
scenarios.description: A person has been in a motel paid for by a church for the past week. The church can only pay for 2 more nights.
scenarios.question: What is their current status for CE?

options.D: Must be assessed before voucher ends

scenarios.explanation: Motel stays paid by non-profit organizations are considered housed situations. They would become eligible once they no longer have the motel option. See manual pages 31, 32, 42 for detailed information.

scenarios.title: Returning from Treatment
scenarios.description: Someone completed a 30-day residential substance abuse treatment program yesterday. They have no home to return to and slept outside last night.
scenarios.question: What is their eligibility status?

options.B: Not eligible due to recent institutional stay

scenarios.explanation: They are currently literally homeless (slept outside). Recent stays in treatment don't affect eligibility if the person is currently experiencing literal homelessness. See manual pages 31, 32, 42 for detailed information.

scenarios.title: Living in RV
scenarios.description: A person has been living in an RV parked on a friend's property for 6 months. The friend wants them to leave immediately.
scenarios.question: What is their current homelessness status?

options.A: Homeless - RV is not permanent housing
options.B: Housed - they have shelter with permission
options.D: Homeless only if RV lacks utilities

scenarios.explanation: Living in an RV with permission on private property is considered a housed situation. They would need to be living in the RV in a place not meant for habitation to be considered homeless. See manual pages 31, 32, 42 for detailed information.

scenarios.title: Foster Care Aging Out
scenarios.description: A 21-year-old aged out of foster care 3 years ago. They've been couch surfing and are now sleeping in a 24-hour laundromat.
scenarios.question: What factors are relevant for CE assessment?

options.A: Foster care history makes them automatically eligible
options.B: They're eligible due to current unsheltered status
options.C: Must verify foster care history first
options.D: Too old for youth-specific programs only

scenarios.explanation: They are eligible because they're currently unsheltered (laundromat). Foster care history may be relevant for prioritization but doesn't determine eligibility. See manual pages 31, 32, 42 for detailed information.

scenarios.title: Emergency Shelter Wait List
scenarios.description: A person has been on the emergency shelter wait list for 5 days while sleeping outside. The shelter calls saying a bed is available tonight.
scenarios.question: Should CE assessment be completed?

options.B: Yes, complete assessment for long-term planning
options.C: Only if they refuse the shelter bed
options.D: Wait 7 days to see if they stay in shelter

scenarios.explanation: CE assessment should be completed regardless of emergency shelter entry. CE is about assessing for appropriate housing interventions, not just emergency shelter. See manual pages 5, 6, 20 for detailed information.

scenarios.title: Seasonal Worker
scenarios.description: A seasonal farm worker's employment and employer-provided housing ended 3 days ago. They've been sleeping in their car since then.
scenarios.question: What is their homelessness status?

options.D: Must prove they can't return home

scenarios.explanation: They are literally homeless as they're living in a vehicle. Previous housing tied to employment doesn't affect current eligibility if they're now unsheltered. See manual pages 31, 32, 42 for detailed information.
